personal_statement.essay_prompt: Share an essay on any topic of your choice. It can be one you've already written, one that responds to a different prompt, or one of your own design.
personal_statement.personal_statement: Others may not feel the beating heart of the khet (field) that defines my badminton court but I do. It cradles me like a mother carrying her newborn. It inhales for me when my deviated septum becomes a hurdle for my breathing. Spellbound, I chase this shuttlecock as though it wants to be caught - by none other than me - and I oblige: consistently, o so fervently. Giving up is not a choice because I, my racket, my shuttlecock, and my khet make up a team that shares a dream, and I am the only one who can move without assistance. I simply cannot let them down. Even then, do I belong here - fully? Am I not conflicted between two worlds? Both begin with the letters L - London and Lahore. In fact, they even encompass the same amount of alphabets. Yet, they are as different, as antipodal as sports and economics. A part of me will always be in London, the part I left just there in ninth grade when I migrated to Lahore. A triumph of one romantic city over another. Or was it? Conflicted, I find myself often disconcerted even when amongst my people, in a khet my ancestors took pride in; so much so, that I feel like a shadow. I feel as though I am some traitor - one who could not master my mother tongue. Even then, my khet took me in, humbled me, taught me lessons, gave me uncountable chances, and made me the man I am. More than anything, it offered me the joy of badminton. How can I ever repay the debt? How can I confess my love to it in its two languages, Urdu and Punjabi, that I still remain imperfect in? Somehow giving back, I disallow my crooked septum from hindering my badminton pursuits. This has seemingly progressed into a passion, a conviction - one that I need as much as I need that poorly passed-through oxygen. Fate, however, offers bigger plans. Is it my hard work, determination, or just a miracle? I do not know but following a landmark number of trials and hospital admissions, I ended up in the Pakistan National Badminton team and then the Pakistan Badminton Federation Team’s Under-17 Cohort. Finally, I acquired answers for my identity: this nation owns me and I own it too. I finally feel as though I have given back to my nation in my way. There is freedom; there is felicity in this realization that only my shuttlecock can understand as it flies across to my opponents. Henceforth, I shine in my community because of the shine of my seven gold and four silver medals. They see me as a symbol of hope - something people of my country need now more than ever. And so I know my purpose: I need to do more; I need to expand my horizons, and take inspiration from my long-term companion - my shuttlecock - which has the mobility that Pakistan needs. I must be led by the spirits of my people to become the best version of myself, just as my racket pushes the shuttlecock. So forth, I move towards another, perhaps even stronger passion: policy making. Commencing with eco-policy, I attended the “Green Print for Change, Navigating the Policy Landscape in Environmental Stewardship” conference on Climate Change and Environmental Sustainability. Just as my shuttlecock bounces between me and my opponent, I successfully bounce between badminton, physiotherapy, and activism. Through each publication, experiment, and regression analysis, I feel as though I am fulfilling a promise - to the very khet that grounds me. With this, my goals became clearer: I can make Pakistan as mobile, as fast-paced as my shuttlecock. I can and I will - stronger than the force that I exert on my racket, stronger than the suffocation that my deviated septum induces.

education_progression.explanation: Shortly after completing my O Levels in 2021, my mother suffered a severe heart attack, leaving her in critical condition. With limited medical facilities in Multan, we relocated to Lahore, where she underwent angioplasty and angiography. As the eldest child, I took on the responsibility of caring for her and supporting my younger siblings while my father continued working in Multan. This significant change in our family dynamic made it challenging for me to attend school consistently. Her recovery was a long and demanding process, during which I stayed home to manage her care and support my siblings. Balancing these responsibilities required me to adjust my educational trajectory, but I remained committed to my learning despite these obstacles, and by end of 2022, I resumed my academic journey, transitioning to A Levels later
education_progression.school_change_reasoning: In 2021, shortly after completing my O Levels, my mother fell critically ill, and we had to make the decision to relocate from Multan to Lahore for her treatment, as better healthcare facilities were available there. As a result, I had to leave my school in Multan. In Lahore, I initially looked into continuing my education at Beaconhouse, but their A Level program didn’t offer the subjects I wanted to pursue. After some searching, I found The Lyceum, which provided the required subjects which aligned better with my educational aspirations.

short_essay_1.response: Growing up in Lahore, I’ve witnessed the loss of greenery each year due to urban sprawl, with parks disappearing and concrete taking over. As rapid urbanization continues, the environmental consequences are barely acknowledged. Through Bryn Mawr's interdisciplinary approach, I can expand on my understanding of environmental issues and develop solutions for developing countries, with courses like ENVS B202-001 and ENVS B350-002 equipping me to address societal impacts and promote urban greening. Engaging with the Environmental Club and drawing from my work with my NGO, Aab o Hawa, I look forward to helping implement programs for green infrastructure and tree canopy expansion. Where courses like “Modern Urbanisms” and “Narratives of Identity” would let me connect my passions for storytelling and sustainable societal development in a meaningful way, Bryn Mawr's Katharine Houghton Hepburn Center would provide a unique platform to turn these ideas into action. The opportunity to engage with diverse perspectives through Tri-College Consortium while maintaining the intimacy of a smaller college environment feels like the perfect balance for me. Bryn Mawr is the perfect place for me to grow academically and contribute meaningfully to greening urban spaces.

short_essay_2.prompt: Bryn Mawr students bring their authentic selves to campus. What do you know about yourself to be true—and what in your background or experience led you to that truth? (250-500 words)
short_essay_2.response: On the last day before summer break, our filmmaking club tasked us with selecting a theme for a documentary, ‘The Faces of Pakistan’ As our group of storytellers brainstormed ideas about education reform, urban poverty, disappearing crafts, one friend, recently moved from Karachi, suggested we focus on Pakistan's rivers: their culture, traditions, and their daily lives. And so,’Darya ki Kahaniyan’ (Tales of the River) began to take shape. The first day of filming was chaotic. We traveled to a small riverside village near Shakoor Lake in Badin district, with our equipment piled into a rickety van, greeted by the sight that left us both curious and unsettled. Fishermen moved with quiet determination, their silhouettes framed against the shimmering, polluted river. Their weary boats, made of aging wood, were lined up in the murky brown water. The water surface was slick with oil and dotted with clumps of blackish green algae. A pungent mix of ammonia assaulted our senses, making it hard to breathe. Our first interview was with an elderly fisherman named Ghulam. His hands were weathered and calloused, face deeply lined, and his voice heavy and worn. He wore a faded kurta, its color lost to time and countless washes, "The river was alive," his eyes glistening. "But now,it’s choking.The water smells of chemicals. The fish are fewer, smaller, and weaker." He spoke of the factories upstream dumping waste into the water, once-clear rivers became contaminated with chemicals, plastics, and toxins. “Ab toh kuch bhi nahi bacha.” (There is nothing left now), he finished. Here I realized that pollution and urbanization are not isolated; my urban environment and their rural one were intricately linked, and the choices we make in cities ripple outward in ways we often fail to see. Each interview brought a new revelation. There was the young father who struggled to feed his family because his daily catch had dwindled to a fraction of what it used to be, and a single mother who worked tirelessly repairing old nets, but still couldn't make enough to support her children. The more we filmed, the more I realized this wasn't just a fisherman's story—it was about all of us, with urban waste and unchecked industrialization choking the river and its people. The camera became more than just a tool; it became a link between two worlds that rarely acknowledged one another. The documentary, which started as a school project, grew into something far bigger. We submitted ‘Darya ki Kahaniyan’ to the National Amateur Short Film Festival (NASFF). Our film won the award for Best Short Documentary. The greatest reward came weeks later when, spurred by the documentary, the Pakistan Environmental Protection Agency launched a cleanup initiative, penalized factories, imposed stricter regulations, and began efforts to restore the river’s ecosystem. Through ‘Darya ki Kahaniyan’, I realized that I have the power to bring hidden stories to light and to incite action. I’m not just an observer, but an active participant in creating change where it's needed.

personal_statement.essay_prompt: Share an essay on any topic of your choice. It can be one you've already written, one that responds to a different prompt, or one of your own design.
personal_statement.personal_statement:
My first act of reclamation was to plant wild native grasses—Cymbopogon—to revive the neglected plots behind my home. Before I could make sense of the devastation around me, my hands were already digging.  I learned early on that the ground beneath our feet is alive with possibility if you know where to look. My hometown: Chakwal’s soil, once teeming with life, was now suffocated by the creeping sprawl of unchecked industrial development. But I refused to let it die.

As a child, my most cherished memories are of running barefoot through the countryside, the air thick with the scent of rain-soaked earth. But slowly - the greed of modernity reached Chakwal and it succumbed to the sprawl of factories; it is an indescribably helpless condition - to be in love with the world around you and witness its decay, powerless to challenge a system built on never ending greed. When this sprawl of decay started forcing my community to relocate - abandoning their homes, memorabilia and sustenance, I realized, we, no I, couldn’t let this happen, not without a fight.

I started with rain barrels—rudimentary systems at first, fashioned from reused plastic drums. I worked with local women to construct underground rainwater harvesting systems, ensuring that every drop was accounted for. We planted moisture-loving Typha along the edges of the barrels, soft cattails that thrived with just enough water and signaled where the soil was fertile once more. 

Us women, who were already burdened with household duties, became the invisible victims of environmental degradation. As water sources dried up, it was us who traveled further and further to fetch what little was left. The smoke from factories blackened the air, increasing respiratory illnesses among the elderly and children. We were already marginalized in so many ways, now had to bear the brunt of environmental collapse, and no one seemed to notice. This injustice ignited my ambition. If no one would listen to the cries of my fellow women, I would make them hear.

As I worked to rebuild Chakwal’s women and natural spaces, I turned my attention to the larger picture. How could we develop in a way that didn’t destroy? My question took me deep into the policies that governed rural development. What I found was a system so blind to the nuances of environmental justice that it perpetuated the very inequalities it should be solving. I authored a research paper analyzing the effects of climate change on women’s health in rural Pakistan, focusing specifically on Chakwal. The water scarcity here was no longer just an environmental issue; it was a gendered one. The same policies that failed to protect the environment also ignored the lives of women.

I knew that change couldn’t happen in isolation, so I began leading groups of women in rainwater management projects. Together, we built cisterns and underground storage systems, securing water for 50 families in our village. We planted drought-resistant varieties of Acacia modesta, a tree native to Chakwal, along the peripheries of our homes, their roots digging deep into the parched earth, holding it together in the face of erosion.

We, the women of Chakwal, with their hands buried in the earth, became part of a larger movement to reclaim what was lost. Each plant we sow, every system we build, is a protest against the destruction of our homeland. Every Prosopis seedling, a tree that can thrive in drought-ridden areas, is witness to our ability to reclaim what industry had taken. We are telling the world that we refused to disappear into the smog.

My commitment to environmental justice remains unshaken. I have seen firsthand how policy can destroy lives, but I have also witnessed the power of community-led change. No matter how much is taken, we have the power to grow it back, stronger than ever before. And I am determined to make sure that what has been lost will be reclaimed.

short_essay_1.response:
Since I was a child, I have seen women in Chakwal walk for miles balancing metal pitchers of water on their heads every morning. Their hands, calloused from weight, showed unyielding strength. But these stories were brushed off. Driven by their strength, I spearheaded DEAP’s “Water for All” program, installing more than 210 taps and enabling 1,200 families easy access to water. It was a realization that from that day forward, every drop of water flowing through those taps was a mark of change—a step toward equity.

At Harvard, I would hope to share these experiences in conversations within classes like “Women, Gender, and Society” or “Resilience and Climate Adaptation,” bridging the goal of achieving global gender equity with that of creating scalable solutions. My journey in amplifying the voices of rural women—be it through photo exhibitions or rainwater harvesting campaigns—will inform my approach amongst Harvard’s diverse community, allowing for serendipitous solutions that intertwine heart with action.

short_essay_2.prompt: Briefly describe an intellectual experience that was important to you.
short_essay_2.response:
With camera in hand, I squatted down by a well, the sun casting golden hue over the fields of my village. Through my lens, I captured the frame of a woman balancing a clay pot on her head, her silhouette traced with dust circling in the air. Her quiet strength inspired me, but when I displayed these images to illuminate the resilience of rural women, one male elder dismissed my work. "Why interfere? They’ve been doing it fine for centuries," he added.

Rather than argue, I invited him to meet me the next day. Watching the women lug heavy pots and trudge back home, he saw their struggles through new eyes. His earlier dismissal morphed into reluctant respect as he nodded.

Through it all, I learned the ability of storytelling to alter perceptions. At Harvard, I aspire to bridge divides through empathy and action.

short_essay_4.prompt: Briefly describe any of your extracurricular activities, employment experience, travel, or family responsibilities that have shaped who you are.
short_essay_4.response:
Growing up in Chakwal, where even traveling between cities felt like a big deal, flying seemed like a distant dream. My parents always accompanied me, handling the travel details. However, when I was selected for a summer program at Oxford, I knew I had to step out of my comfort zone. My first trip to the airport was overwhelming—crowds, terminals, and me managing everything on my own.

The real challenge came with flying. As someone with a deep fear of heights, the idea of being in a plane terrified me. But I asked myself, could I let this fear stop me from reaching my goal? That question helped me face my fear. The view from above was worth it, and I made it! This experience taught me that when you believe in yourself, you can overcome any challenge. Today, I’m confident, independent, and ready to tackle whatever comes my way.

short_essay_4.prompt: Briefly describe any of your extracurricular activities, employment experience, travel, or family responsibilities that have shaped who you are.
short_essay_4.response:
Growing up in Chakwal, where even traveling between cities felt like a big deal, flying seemed like a distant dream. My parents always accompanied me, handling the travel details. However, when I was selected for a summer program at Oxford, I knew I had to step out of my comfort zone. My first trip to the airport was overwhelming—crowds, terminals, and me managing everything on my own.

The real challenge came with flying. As someone with a deep fear of heights, the idea of being in a plane terrified me. But I asked myself, could I let this fear stop me from reaching my goal? That question helped me face my fear. The view from above was worth it, and I made it! This experience taught me that when you believe in yourself, you can overcome any challenge. Today, I’m confident, independent, and ready to tackle whatever comes my way.

short_essay_5.prompt: Please briefly elaborate on one of your academic interests or plans for your education.
short_essay_5.response:
When suffering feels normal, change seems impossible. As a child, I witnessed the harsh reality of gender inequality, where women faced severe restrictions and violence, their voices silenced and their rights ignored. At the same time, floods repeatedly destroyed my city, Chakwal, devastating farmers’ crops and leaving communities helpless.

Picture the same child who once saw her world devastated by floods and gender inequality, now transformed into a government officer at Chakwal. At Harvard, with frameworks like GSD’s workshops on Landscape Architecture and Urban Resilience, I now know how to create sustainable land use strategies that reduce floods and protect my community. Harvard Law School's Gender Violence Program has empowered me to advocate for women’s rights and confront gender-based violence. My majors in Environmental Science and Gender Studies have provided me with the tools to heal the wounds I once witnessed.

Hey roomie! 

I'm Eshal, a Sherlock Holmes aficionado always hunting for the next mystery. Whether it's turning a casual walk into an investigation or sneaking off for spontaneous adventures, I'm all about fun, snacks, and a touch of detective work. 

And of course, as the youngest in my family, I've mastered being the unofficial assistant—always ready to grab your phone charger or fetch that last snack from across the room. It’s all part of my charm, and I can't wait to make you feel at home here.

You might catch me tearing up when Pakistan loses, but don't worry—the next win will have me celebrating like we’ve won the World Cup. Expect spontaneous match commentary, dramatic gasps, and maybe even a victory dance or two! Let’s turn our place into the ultimate cricket haven, where every match feels like the final!

personal_statement.essay_prompt: Reflect on a time when you questioned or challenged a belief or idea. What prompted your thinking? What was the outcome?
personal_statement.personal_statement:
In the glare of the spotlight, where judgments drown out the music, my 'payal' (anklet) sings a different tune. Its chimes, echo ancient rhythms, defying every whisper of doubt, declaring my space on the stage regardless of the gendered norms that define this dance, my dance. As I twirl, a question lingers: In the grand dance of life, do identities shape our movements, or do movements shape identities, a grand scheme of constructionism and conformity?

I move my body in uninhibited agility; the thrum of my soles hitting the floor, enraptured by the Saraiki folk tunes. My feet pirouette in a trance, every step resounding with the memory of my father’s violence: ‘Khusra! (Crossdresser), his voice echoed as his belt lashed across my back, ‘Mere betay ko sab Chaka samjhainge?’ (You want people to think my son is transgender?) he bellows as his palms collide with my shoulders, shoving me into the wall.

Conformity leaves no space for my expression of self to exist outside the binaries of gender. There is no sanctuary where my gender ceases to exist and the only echo that resounds is that of my payal. Beautiful and complete in its entirety, free from the labels that gender enforces my passion into. How could I not resent these social dictums that preclude me from pursuing my passions on the mere basis of gender?

As if synchronized with the pulse of my moves, my uncles offer deprecating provocations. ‘Hassaingay sab iss per’ (People will make a mockery of him). It is alleged that my devotion to this craft entails moral depravity, threatening the very foundations of what constitutes masculinity. The constant barrage of pejoratives diminishes my courage to perform at any public avenue. If only this dance were as simple to abandon as society presumes! So with a heavy heart, I left my home in Mianwali and moved to Islamabad.

However, once this alien city transforms into a home for me, a familiar mockery begins to rear its head. Despite its infrastructural generosity and claims of progressivist thinking, my optimism stutters when I recognize the same disdain towards men voluntarily pursuing dance existing in Islamabad. And thus, I am once again rendered a pariah over my so-called effeminate conduct, with nowhere left to go, I turn inward, towards my payal, my jhoomar.

Ignoring all the denunciation, I continue to dance, harmonizing my twirls with the agony I have faced. Matching each strike of my father’s with a resounding thump of my adorned feet against the floor. Henceforth, my healing begins, a source from within. My dance now takes form in another light, before a mere passion, now it is a journey. One I craft myself from inception to end, a performance I name ‘Zoh’, after myself; Because now with my soul slowly breaking free, I understand what resilience looks like, my passion is proof of my ambition to persist, to keep dancing no matter the wound.

Following the titillating echoes of my payal, I find others like me. Together, we build a sanctuary: “Jhoomar” (Dancers), a dance collective that choreographs beats and rhythms to the assuaging capacities of music therapy. Encapsulating the essence of my personal dance journey, this initiative seeks to amplify the remedial potency of dance. Our collective endeavors are designed not only to craft movements that act as a therapeutic medium, enhancing emotional well-being but also to narrate cultural stories that challenge and transcend toxic stereotypes. Through Jhoomar, I am finally discovering acceptance, coming a long way from being labeled a cultural renegade for my unorthodox preoccupation.

Orthodoxies, at the end of the day, are social constructs: what may be to you, may not be to me. There is no must! No matter which form I metamorph into next, one truth stands: if the world silences the music, I would still dance to the cadence of my soul and the chime of my payal.

education_progression.explanation: In 2022, my mother was diagnosed with Ulcerative Colitis. I needed to help at home, as I was the eldest son. Also, the medical expenses of healthcare process had become a burden, so I took a year off from high school to help at home with household chores and the healthcare of my mother. I simultaneously worked as a part-time tutor of O and A level science subjects to cope with the financial burdens. Though it was a year off high school, I indulged in other academic and co-curricular activities like the ‘Jhoomar’ initiative, research in particle physics, and independently studied for A-level subjects including Physics, Chemistry, Biology, and Mathematics, scoring perfect grades in the upcoming year. I believe the gap year was a great choice as it helped me connect with my family after 3 years of boarding school and helped me explore other interests.
education_progression.school_change_reasoning: I left Cadet College Hasanabdal after graduating to pursue further subjects of A levels. In August 2023, I joined Supernova School Islamabad to pursue further Cambridge A-level courses including, Computer Sciences, Psychology, Art and Design, and German to be taken over the year. Furthermore, as I had graduated from a boarding school with limited accessibilities, now I wanted to address my non-academic interests including a startup NGO, Field Hockey, and Calligraphy. I further utilized my year by participating and eventually winning a scientific research competition by CERN and earning myself a trip to Switzerland for the summer.

short_essay_1.response:
Holding Amma’s hand, I caressed its creases–etched by time and experience; a roadmap of stories–recalling her struggles. One pictures her gripping tightly onto the rusty bars of the cabin that drove to the nearest town, where she would teach. Another speaks tales of her patience; days, months, years of extra hours, and endless sacrifices to provide for her children’s education. One’s perspectives on adversities tell a lot about their perspective on anything: Her will to dream, her strength to endure, her passion to bring change.

I may not have my mother’s circumstances but I have her perspectives.

The reassuring touch of her creases highlights the way for me to navigate every challenge in life: from leading the first-ever Pakistani team at CERN–battling limiting resources, and opportunities–to each field hockey tournament in Punjab, In the light of my perspectives shaped by Mother’s stories, I have persevered.

At Harvard, through simple conversations crossing Harvard Square; complex experiments at the LPPC; taking classes, writing essays; or dancing with Harvard AADT proudly representing my culture, I wish to share not only my identity but my stories—my perspectives.

Holding Amma’s hands beside mine I realise they mirror creases.
“We share destinies, Mother!” I say.

short_essay_2.prompt: Briefly describe an intellectual experience that was important to you.
short_essay_2.response:
The tires are stuck. The fuel is running out, The plane HAS TO land. I rush to be the savior…grip the landing gear…AND…. 

Buzz! The power’s out! 

No, it was not me saving the 435 lives, It was Krish (the movie)—in the TV; only until the power went out–as usual. 

So while he played with his superpowers, I decided to use mine–my brain–and rectify the situation.

I find myself and Uncle Jabbar grappling with equations, DC to AC conversions, wire maps on the whiteboard, a car battery, a solar panel, and a bit of passion–all connected to a UPS.

Viola, the tv is back on.  

“Zindagi mein akar bakar karte raho, kuch na kuch ho jata hai!”

Uncle Jabbar’s words of nerdy wisdom are etched around the greater narrative of life: in Haywire circumstances, adaptability, the most valuable instinct man possesses, is not always acceptance but creativity.

In our adventure, chaotically intertwining essentials from the garage and the rooftop to the TV lounge, we had not created the Quantum computer–nor did we save the plane–but we had created something new. The chaos of the human mind is the essence of innovation!

P.S. The plane grew wings—it’s Bollywood!

short_essay_3.prompt: Extracurricular, employment, travel, or family experiences
short_essay_3.response:
I am a rock hound. I have many valuable possessions, emeralds, scapolites, and spinels. but on the top of my rack is a precious memory: A painted butterfly on a broken Ghara (Earthen Pot).

“Shukriya Bhae, but I already ate. Can you buy me a color-box instead?”

Ali denies the pack of cookies. amidst weeks of food campaigns with my team, he had never refused. Standing at the entrance of the Ghara shop, where he would work, I questioned the real reason behind this playful wish, "Was there something to hide?"

Yes, there was.

Ali did not go to school—He could not. Instead, he worked at the Ghara shop owned by his Uncle Muneeb. He rushed inside to bring a color book, his most prized possession, one he had bought saving from his minimum wage; along with it, a piece of a broken ghara and a pencil made out of sharpened coal. He drew a butterfly.

Realizing the need for a different approach, we not only distributed food packs the next day; we also distributed books–and a color-box. After a year of fundraising, we inaugurated a small school; a canvas for Ali and many others to paint their dreams on.

short_essay_4.prompt: Your plans for your college education
short_essay_4.response:
“How do we measure what we cannot see?”

This enigma always made me feel like a detective; from revealing the tiniest of discoveries like the neutron mass to the cosmic-scaled quests of the Universe, Physics has been my mystery. 

I practiced my detective skills while experimenting at CERN–collaborating with the American team, Myriad Magnets, and scientists from around the world. We used detectors to measure beam composition at different beam momenta; intrigued by the undiscovered horizons of possibilities in high-energy Physics, the detective found his calling as a particle physicist.

At Harvard, studying courses including PHYSICS-389: The Standard Model and Beyond, and 145: Elementary Particles, I hope to establish a vivid theoretical understanding of Particle Physics. Working under renowned professors Melissa Franklin, and John Huth–in light of their experience of the ATLAS and the CMS experiment–and with opportunities like the LPPC, I hope to gain an experimental skill set that I will operationalize by contributing to future upcoming experiments including the CDF II.

Arming myself with the experiences, knowledge, and values I gain at Harvard, I see myself not just as a physicist, but as a passionate educationist striving for the provision of scientific education in my home country Pakistan.

short_essay_5.response:
Hey roomie!

Ever eaten a Jalebi? 

Well, here I am!

And here’s my story:

“Kaha tha over dribble na karna–JALEBI.” 
After being ridiculed by my coach and the whole team for a lost field hockey match–a result of me making Jalebis (Pretzel shapes) with the ball and eventually losing its control to the opponent for the nth time–I earned the everlasting, ever-known title of Jalebi. 

Upon perpetual allocation of this historic cuisine to my personality, whether at social dinners or hockey tournaments, I realized that I almost embody this celebrated Pakistani sweet dish. 

(At this point, I urge you to google it and visually appreciate it).

The sugary syrup captured in its crusty layers encapsulates warmth and sweetness, qualities I strive to embody. The intricate twists and curls signal joy and surprise (Disclaimer: this is a warning for my spontaneous Bhangra dance episodes). Jalebi’s soft texture radiates love and compassion as it melts; this scrumptious delight, with its vibrant golden shades and tenderness, is one of a kind–and so am I. Indeed, Jalebi is a well-suited nickname.

For all the awesome adventures awaiting us at Harvard, I can’t wait to celebrate your stories and share more of mine.

personal_statement.essay_prompt: Share an essay on any topic of your choice. It can be one you've already written, one that responds to a different prompt, or one of your own design.
personal_statement.personal_statement:
Za-har?-mun (She-dreamed) 
Za-har?-yam (He-dreamed) 

Same longing — different futures — determined by the weight of gendered grammar. In my village dreams are verbs only men can conjugate. A girl’s aspirations are tethered to the confines of the kitchen, our ambition as disposable as the onion skins we peel. But, you see, dreams have a peculiar resilience: they persist, even when silenced, and my Amma’s (mother) silence taught me to listen closely…. 

Amidst evenings filled with stitching and cooking, I sensed her yearning for what she was denied: education, freedom, autonomy. Hers was a world of nailah-jabir? (unjust necessity), where even the act of learning English marked one as ghair (foreign), kafir (infidel). When I declared my interest in studying Aramaic and Hebrew, the murmurs turned to outrage. “This is be-deen (against the faith),” they said. My love for languages was painted as a betrayal of my identity, a refusal against norms that kept women tethered to what was deemed “acceptable.” 

But my father shielded me from these accusations. He witnessed my care for the books I found in Sunday thrift markets, and the clay piggy bank which I emptied monthly to purchase a new research paper. He knew — I meant no harm — I only wanted knowledge, a right, my right; as important for me as it is for a man. Together, my parents became my refuge, insisting that I could be za-har?-mun-da-hawa-yam (she-dreamed-of-flight). 

Za-parh?-mun (She-read) 
Za-parh?-yam (He-read) 

In learning languages — English, Aramaic, and later Persian and Hebrew — I discovered a medium of resistance.  

Aramic: “Let no one be lost to time,” a reminder of my mother’s sacrifices.  

Hebrew: “The world stands on three things: truth, justice, and peace,” gave me a framework for my advocacy. 

Persian: “A stone may stay in water for a long time, but it remains unsoaked,” mirrored the endurance I sought to embody.  

Za-da-lafz-ghair-yam (She-spoke-the-foreign) 

With Global Sisterhood Network (GSN), I formed a multilingual team advocating for women’s rights across 13 languages, connecting over 1,000 women — from Pakistan to Egypt. Language was my weapon, but it was also my salve. I trained volunteers to translate resources, guiding women to learn about their rights in legal systems that often ignored their dialects. 

In one case, I worked with a woman from a Punjabi village whose story of domestic violence had been dismissed by authorities because she couldn’t communicate in Urdu. With the support of Global Sisterhood Network, her voice finally carried the weight it deserved, and her husband faced legal consequences. 

Za-difa?-mun (She-defended) 
Za-difa?-yam (He-defended) 

Same resistance — different recognition. Advocacy is often an act of unlearning before it becomes action. My linguistic excavations showed me that systemic inequality is not just a policy failure but a failure to listen. Words like lakir (boundary) and baradari (kinship) had been weaponized in my village to confine women. At GSN, we showed that a boundary can be a line of protection, and kinship can extend to sisterhood. 

Za-da-hawa-sang?n-yam (I-flew-through-storms) 

Through GSN, I began to see that language as a framework for existence. My advocacy is a verb, a dream I will dare to conjugate no matter if I am not a man; for it is one conjugated in every dialect spoken by the women I’ve worked with. 

As I sit with women in remote villages, helping them draft legal documents in Punjabi or translate their rights into Arabic, I think back to Amma. Her silence was not consent; it was survival. Every word I speak, every sentence I translate, is a continuation of the flight she once dreamed of but could not take. Language is my lens, my mirror, and my weapon, but most of all, it is my possibility — my way to create a world where no woman’s story is lost in translation.

short_essay_1.prompt: As a research institution that also prides itself on its liberal arts curriculum, Princeton allows students to explore areas across the humanities and the arts, the natural sciences, and the social sciences. What academic areas most pique your curiosity, and how do the programs offered at Princeton suit your particular interests? (Please respond in 250 words or fewer)
short_essay_1.response:
In 57 minutes, I deciphered a linguistic puzzle, isolating phoneme patterns and applying probabilistic methods to reconstruct syntax — a feat rare even among seasoned competitors. The fastest solution in our group, it bridged computational logic with linguistic intuition, propelling us to the Finals at the International Linguistics Olympiad. 

At Princeton, my passion for linguistics finds its home in LIN355: Field Methods in Linguistics and LIN304: Introduction to Machine Translation, where I will learn to apply computational techniques to analyze and preserve endangered languages. Combining my interest in Classics and Gender Studies, specifically through CLA 329 - Sex and Gender in Antiquity and GSS 420 - Feminist Theory, I will explore how language and power have historically intertwined. I’m also drawn to COS 324: Intro to Machine Learning, where I can build upon my work as a research assistant using ML to interpret Egyptian hieroglyphs. 

The Humanities Council’s “Pathways to Language Justice” and the Indigenous Studies Interdisciplinary Group particularly excite me. Having founded Global Sisterhood Network, where we translated legal resources into 13 languages for women, I’ve witnessed the urgent need for linguistic equity.

Princeton's interdisciplinary ethos—where linguistics can converge with AI, classics, and gender theory—is ideal for a student like me who sees language not merely as communication, but as resistance, preservation, and empowerment.

short_essay_2.prompt: Your Voice Princeton values community and encourages students, faculty, staff and leadership to engage in respectful conversations that can expand their perspectives and challenge their ideas and beliefs. As a prospective member of this community, reflect on how your lived experiences will impact the conversations you will have in the classroom, the dining hall or other campus spaces. What lessons have you learned in life thus far? What will your classmates learn from you? In short, how has your lived experience shaped you? (500 words or fewer)
short_essay_2.response:
“Purdah” (veil) 

“Chaar Diwari” (four walls) 

“Ghairat” (honor) 

Synonyms for subjugation — declarations that to exist as a woman is to trespass.  

“Be-haya” (shameless) is reserved for those who speak too loudly;  

“Be-izzat” (dishonored) is for those who dare to say no.  

A stark example: Sadaf, my cousin who became a cautionary tale for all the women in my family. 

Sadaf, was attacked by a man, emboldened by a culture that deems rejection as rebellion, who threw acid on her for refusing his marriage proposal. Hundreds of cases of acid attacks are reported annually in Pakistan, but most go unacknowledged, buried under the weight of “izzat” (family honor). In our linguistic prison, whispers spread faster than her scars healed: “Girls shouldn’t provoke men.” 

For months, I lived with a choking fear. I avoided mirrors, worried that I might one day reflect Sadaf’s fate. Words that were supposed to "protect" me —“chup” (silence), “modesty”, “obedience”—became iron bars. But words cut both ways.  

In my isolation, I stumbled across stories of survival: Rukhsana, who rebuilt her life after an acid attack by opening her own clothing business; the work of Dr. Fouzia Saeed, whose advocacy redefined workplace harassment laws; Ayesha Siddiqa’s Military Inc., which dissected power structures with unapologetic precision. These were revolutions written by women who refused to be erased. 

And then, I met Sadaf again, whose words have stayed with me ever since. 

"Don’t pity me," Her courage to live had been forged in pain, and in the face of such power I refused to stay in fear. 

For Sadaf’s courage – for mine, and the countless women who live in fear this system sows, I founded Faces of Courage, my declaration that we as women would no longer hide. With a team of eight, we taught 50 survivors vocational and creative skills, organized mental health workshops, and secured six jobs through partnerships with NGOs. But the work was more than numbers. It was in the hands of women stitching embroidery for the first time, their fingers hesitant but determined. It was in the laughter of a survivor learning to paint, reclaiming the brush that her attacker thought he’d stolen forever. 

The opposition was relentless. “Why teach them skills?” “Why give them jobs?” Acid attack survivors, to many, are unworthy of a second chance, relegated to lives hidden in shame. I was accused of disrupting the “natural order,” of tarnishing my family’s name by speaking out. But if speaking against power is a sin, I’ve learned to wear it as a badge of honor. 

At first, my voice trembled; now it resounds. I burn with courage, as does every woman who has walked through the doors of Faces of Courage. Sadaf taught me that words can imprison, but they can also ignite. “Hope,” “resistance”—these are the words we now live by. 

I see a world where women are no longer confined by language but freed by it; a narrative I rewrite every day.

short_essay_3.prompt: Princeton has a longstanding commitment to understanding our responsibility to society through service and civic engagement. How does your own story intersect with these ideals? (250 words or fewer)
short_essay_3.response:
Every evening at home, I speak Burushaski with my family — spoken by only 2,400 people in my rural town. Among classmates and competitions I’ve attended across Pakistan, no one has heard of my language, let alone speaks it. For my grandparents, who learned Urdu and Punjabi as adults to integrate into wider society, Burushaski is their soul — a living archive of which we are the museums.  

Language preservation wasn’t always my calling. That began with Ashraf, the local bookseller who handed me a copy of The Lightning Thief: my foray into Greek mythology. That one book cascaded into a love for the languages and histories, but alongside my awe came the heartbreak of realizing they were gone.  

Their decline mirrored Burushaski, and that realization lit a fire in me to act before my language, too, became a relic. I began small: creating a three-dialect dictionary with my school’s language society and uploading it to a website I designed. To draw attention to the language’s precarious state, I designed apparel printed with Burushaski phrases — turning an endangered tongue into a conversation starter.  

But I knew I couldn’t stop there. My research project on decoding Egyptian hieroglyphs using machine-learning showed me the vast potential of technology in preserving dying languages. Now, I dream of developing computational tools to analyze linguistic structures and create digital-archives for endangered languages like Burushaski.  

My language is my identity and I hope to take these efforts global, ensuring no language is lost to silence.

Her core identity—as a computational linguist leveraging AI to preserve endangered languages and fight for women’s rights—permeates every layer of her application. From decoding Egyptian hieroglyphs using machine learning to founding the Global Sisterhood Network across 13 languages, her work is deeply original, community-centered, and scalable. The intellectual maturity shown in her independent research papers rivals that of college juniors. Her essays exemplify Ethan Sawyer’s principles—specificity, transformation, and vulnerability—especially through metaphoric prose and code-switching that demonstrate emotional and linguistic fluency. As admissions officers, we look for students who will not only thrive in academic settings but also transform campus culture. Aaima fits the Princeton mold of service-oriented scholarship, the Stanford maker mindset, and MIT’s hands-on approach to impact. Her lived experience as a Pakistani girl navigating linguistic boundaries and systemic patriarchy gives her a distinct lens on global equity, which she translates into real-world solutions—from trilingual dictionaries to legal aid for rural women. She is not a student who fits the mold. She redefines it. This is the kind of application that excites a committee not just for what the student has done—but for what she will build next. She is the future of the liberal arts in the age of algorithms.

personal_statement.essay_prompt: Share an essay on any topic of your choice. It can be one you've already written, one that
personal_statement.personal_statement: “Zakhm toh mitti mein bhi lagte hain” (even soil can bear wounds) The first time I saw disease, it was in the soil of a field we could never call our own. We are Kashmiri migrants — tillers but never owners, laborers bound to feudal lords tethered to ideals of entrenched discrimination. The disdain of the upper caste landowners (chowdhuries) spread through the community like gossypium wilt. Whispers of “yeh Kashmiri log” (these Kashmiris) seep into the cracks of our lives and education is denied to us – as though literacy is a luxury reserved for the soil’s owners, not its servants. Abba, however, refused to let the blight of this ostracism seep into my destiny. So, while my hands harvested another man’s crop by day, my nights were spent poring over stolen glimpses of school books, their ink a promise that I might one day heal more than fields. In the fields, pathogens attack weakened roots. When I finally entered school, it was not without whispers of protest from the same community that had relegated us to the periphery. “Yeh log padh kar kya karenge?” (What will these people accomplish through education?) But I learned: to read, write and observe. In the yellowing citrus orchards surrounding our village, I noticed a sickness spreading through the trees: Huanglongbing (HLB), a bacterial disease that devastates citrus yields. The pathogen responsible, Candidatus Liberibacter asiaticus, moves stealthily through the veins of the tree. It was here that the metaphor crystallized: if we can decode the DNA of this pathogen, if we can trace its mutations and map its spread, then perhaps we can do the same for the diseases that corroded human systems — inequality, ostracism, prejudice. Abba’s sacrifices — moving to a city rent house so I can hold a pen instead of a plow — propelled me into research. At the Punjab Agriculture Research Center, I developed molecular markers for DNA barcoding Diaphorina citri, the vector of the HLB pathogen. My work centered on amplifying mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase I (COI) and ribosomal ITS2 regions through PCR, a process that mirrors my own experience of amplification: taking the whispers of my Kashmiri identity and making them resonate. Gel electrophoresis confirms product specificity and as I sequence the DNA and identify four genetic clusters among 50 individuals, I think of the ways our own social structures divide us into haplotypes: by caste, ethnicity, religion. Diseases like HLB cannot be eradicated overnight, nor can centuries of systemic inequality. But what they share is a common antidote: targeted intervention. The DNA barcoding technique I developed provides a high-resolution tool for tracking Diaphorina citri variants, enabling region-    specific pest management strategies. Similarly, I realized that understanding the variations within my own community — its histories, its traumas, its strengths—was key to devising solutions. Returning to the village that had once denied me the right to education, I founded a program to teach scientific literacy to young children in my ethnic tribe, many of whom are still barred from attending school. I designed workshops that integrated concepts from my research into hands-on activities, such as mapping phylogenetic trees with colored yarn or simulating PCR with beads and strings. These sessions emulate agency — giving my kin the tools to decode the systems that sought to limit them. When the same chowdhuries ,who had once sneered at my father’s dream for me, attended a community seminar where I presented my findings, their skepticism gave way to curiosity, then respect — an admission that the barriers they had erected are not insurmountable. As I continue my work, I carry with me the lessons of the field: we are all connected by invisible threads — haplotypes in a shared human genome. And so, I persist, ensuring that neither disease nor prejudice will define the harvest of the future. Mitti kabhi haar nahi maanti (the soil never gives up). Nor will I

short_essay_1.prompt: As a research institution that also prides itself on its liberal arts curriculum, Princeton allows students to explore areas across the humanities and the arts, the natural sciences, and the social sciences. What academic areas most pique your curiosity (Please respond in 250 words or fewer)
short_essay_1.response: What captivates me most is its freedom to mix curiosity with innovation (let’s be honest, a dash of trial and error). From chicken farming to experimenting with biology, my journey has been unconventional, to say the least. Take my “barnyard biology” setup, where I used my chickens as test subjects (don’t worry, no feathers were harmed) to experiment with thermal batteries and organic growth patterns. The results? Happy chickens and a whole lot of eggs, which I regularly donate to orphanages—community science at its finest. I’m intrigued by Princeton’s approach to encouraging interdisciplinary connections—because where else could an scientist-in-training with a love for chicken farming also dive into classes on public policy and environmental ethics? I see myself exploring biology, agriculture, and even entrepreneurship through the College’s open curriculum. Princeton’s Environmental Studies Program, with its interdisciplinary approach, offers the perfect platform to connect my work in sustainable farming with academic research. Additionally,who knows, the learnings from Keller Center for Innovation and Entrepreneurship may some day help me take my home-grown research and turn it into a start-up that revolutionizes sustainable farming. Or at the very least, I’ll leave with a deeper understanding of how science and society intertwine (while keeping my chickens happy). Princeton’s mix of academic rigor and flexibility will help me continue asking weird but important questions: How do we feed the world sustainably? And can chickens be the key to it all?

short_essay_2.prompt: Your Voice Princeton values community and encourages students, faculty, staff and leadership to engage in respectful conversations that can expand their perspectives and challenge their ideas and beliefs. As a prospective member of this community, reflect on how your lived experiences will impact the conversations you will have in the classroom, the dining hall or other campus spaces. What lessons have you learned in life thus far? What will your classmates learn from you? In short, how has your lived experience shaped you? (500 words or fewer)
short_essay_2.response: The soil of Sialkot clung to my father’s hands, cracked and calloused from a lifetime of labor, and settled in my mother’s silence—a silence heavier than words, teaching me that love is sacrifice, and strength is quiet endurance. I was born into this soil, its whispers shaping my world: “Don’t dream too big.” “Know your place.” My parents—bound to the earth—poured their lives into survival, a defiance in itself. Yet even as a child, I felt the soil beneath my feet trembling, as if begging me to rise, to break free, to be more than the dust I stood on. When I left Sialkot for Hasanabdal, I thought I’d escaped those whispers, but they clung to me like shadows. In the halls of that boarding school, they took new shapes, new voices: “Kashmiri scientist? Go free Kashmir. Their laughter cut deeper, the walls amplifying their doubt. My dreams felt fragile, trembling under the weight of their scorn. But somewhere deep within me, a quiet defiance stirred—refusing to let the laughter shatter what little hope I carried. In those moments, I turned to what I knew: bridging. I founded Cake Club, a place where prisoners like me could share laughter tearing down barriers we never knew we’d built. However, my heart was still in Sialkot. Every time I returned home,I saw my mother, her hands blistered from work no one acknowledged. She was my first lesson in resilience, but also my first heartbreak. I created Roshan Raasta, for women like Amma, to give them hope to reclaim their voices. Together, we turned barren fields into places of life and dignity. For the first time, I saw my mother smile—not the fleeting smile of endurance, but the unguarded joy of pride. In Sialkot’s fields, citrus greening stole more than crops—it stole my father’s dreams and broke countless hearts. I chased CRISPR-Cas9 research to fight back, and now, by collaborating with Professors at GAO Lab, China, I am pursuing my mission of creating disease-resistant crops—so no dream has to die in the soil again. At Princeton, I will bring these stories—the soil-stained lessons of Sialkot and the sharp edges of Hasanabdal. I will bring the silence of my mother and the defiance of a boy who dared to dream. My classmates will learn that strength is born in the quietest struggles, that community is built one connection at a time, and that even the hardest soil can bloom. This is who I am: the child of soil, the builder of bridges, the dreamer of impossible dreams. And this is the truth I will carry into every conversation: that from pain grows purpose, and from purpose grows change.

short_essay_3.prompt: Princeton has a longstanding commitment to understanding our responsibility to society through service and civic engagement. How does your own story intersect with these ideals? (250 words or fewer)
short_essay_3.response: Seven years before: I tore pages from textbooks—folded them into chips packets to sell on roadside carts. I was given a bat, a rare gift, and I sold it. The money? survival. A fleeting escape. I asked myself, “Kitabon ka kya faida, jab roti ka sawal ho?” ("What good are books when bread is the question?") I used the money donated for education for anything but education. Survival made dreams feel distant, unreachable! But then, CCH came. A chance. A doorway. I saw what could be. What I could be. What my friends could be! Now Books in hand, I walked the dusty paths of my village, my heart heavy with what could have been. Without CCH, I was one of them—children calloused hands, dreams crushed by survival. Generations chained to survival needed a shift—a mindset unshackled from hopelessness. I began “Umeed Ka Safar,” connecting families with public service employees. I sat with parents, pleading, “Bachay khet ke liye nahi, kal ke liye hain” ("Children are for the future, not the fields"). We raised $3k, sending 30+ children to schools, shifting parental mindset from survival to education. Because their dreams could have been mine. And I will fight for them to rise.

application_narrative.overall_analysis:
Ali Hamza Meer’s application succeeds because it weaves together intellectual intensity, social purpose, and cultural rootedness into a cohesive and transformative narrative. His 'spike' is clearly in biology and bioengineering, demonstrated through multiple high-impact research initiatives (e.g., CRISPR, DNA barcoding, microbiome analysis), many of which address urgent real-world problems in agriculture and public health. Yet unlike many science applicants, Ali transcends lab achievements by anchoring his work in a deep understanding of social injustice — caste oppression, rural exclusion, and educational inequity — and channeling his scientific skills toward dismantling those systems. 

From his personal statement’s symbolic use of pathogens and PCR as metaphors for prejudice and identity to his grassroots innovations like TerraWrap and 'Umeed Ka Safar', every component reinforces his central narrative: knowledge as liberation. His leadership is not performative — it’s restorative. He brings education to children and dignity to female farmers. He doesn’t just participate in global research, he repurposes it for marginalized communities.

What makes this application elite-admissions-worthy is its *layered intentionality*: the essays are emotionally intelligent and thematically resonant; the activities show sustained impact and originality; the honors reflect national and international recognition; and the academic-extracurricular synergy is powerful. He models what Jeff Selingo calls a 'service-driven scholar,' and his authentic, unpolished courage — evidenced by quoting Urdu metaphors and building biodegradable plastics from corn husks — reveals a rare synthesis of humility, vision, and intellect. This is not just a compelling applicant. This is the future Princeton hopes to cultivate.

personal_statement.essay_prompt: Share an essay on any topic of your choice. It can be one you've already written, one that
personal_statement.personal_statement: Just look at those laser lights… The symphony of youthful laughter teases me with this toy store’s promises. While they played, I watched and watched - beguiled by these creations they call Toys. What else could lure seven-year-old Omer, other than Toys? Gazing through the thick glass pane, past a mosaic of remote-controlled cars, I was head over heels - for these other-worldly rows laden with Marvel's sturdy action figures. Parked at the street's terminus, the toy store became a daily rendezvous, a haven before and after school. This ‘window shopping’ of mine replaced tangible play - assuaging the solitude of solo bus rides with dreams that lingered until the school bus echoed its piercing horn. Toys……These ones - displayed in ‘WonderToys!’ - seemed different, from the ones I borrowed from neighborhood garbage bins. ‘Pre-loved’ proved a more fitting label than mere junk. Salvaging stray templates and frames, each Toy was a canvas and a challenge - to recycle its past into a new future. Each Toy heralded a long journey of remodeling and re-engineering - resisting society’s readiness to cast it aside as garbage. In my dainty fingers, the toy would cease being trash. Enter Dr. Omer, the conjurer of whimsical transformations; the Creator of Toys! In youthful explorations, playtime sparked a curiosity to unravel the science behind contraptions and repurposing. Lurking within STEM journals, I found inspiration in works like Don Norman's ‘The Design of Everyday Things’ and Samuel Florman's relatable ‘The Existential Pleasures of Engineering.’ Toys thus, became a manifesto for sustainable joy - embodying constant recreation. From Recycled Robot Sculptures made of old tin cans to budget-friendly Virtual Reality Goggles fashioned from discarded eyewear, my little workshop echoed my commitment. Awards like ‘Creator of Engineer’ and ‘Junior Science Champ’ validated my dedication, rooted in a childhood love for Toys and the limitless possibilities they offered. Committed to this devotion, I tenderly touch my lab coat, fueled by the ambition to engineer Toys—this time, for a greater cause. Initiating the Khilonay project, my team of 14 adolescent engineers and I conduct toy-making workshops at The Indus Hospital for children afflicted with the Polio Virus. Mirroring my childhood fascination, we employ recyclable materials for Khilonay - a passion project that believes in every child’s right to play and hence, our duty to engineer: Sketch how recyclable cardboard and metal components can harmonize to form the Toy of your imagination Select recyclable cardboard and salvaged metal parts that align with the design, emphasizing both durability and functionality Assemble a prototype with the chosen materials according to the sketch Add interactive elements to the toy to enhance its appearance Commence playtime! In six months of dedicated effort, we have readied Toys for 277 children, our lab coats endorsing the marks of our tireless labor. Yet, we don't dwell on worn attire; each frayed thread symbolizes a purpose etched on our decorated laboratory coats—a blessing that encapsulates our mission on this planet. Now, I don this very lab coat, as my team goes from crafting Toys to engineering shelter houses - crafting environmentally friendly houses: a traditional mud-brick design paired with eco-friendly insulation. Our innovative layout, tailored for Pakistan's arid regions, promises to lower indoor temperatures by 5°C, making it an optimal choice for pastoral households nationwide. This is not the end; it is just the beginning - of the end of unsustainable, carbon-fuming engineering. It is the beginning of a new era - of creating, composing, and constructing - all without compromising the sanctity of planet Earth. On some days, these will be Toys for the Children of today and tomorrow; on other days these will be shelters for our Citizens. From gazing inside 'WonderToys' to serving both child's joy and humanity - it is a spark of childhood wonder fueling a relentless drive for sustainable and innovative creation.

short_essay_1.prompt: Please describe why you are interested in studying engineering at Princeton. Include any of your experiences in, or exposure to engineering, and how you think the programs offered at the University suit your particular interests. (Please respond in 250 words or fewer)
short_essay_1.response: My blend of traditional mud-brick with modern insulation for cost-effective, eco-friendly housing thrusted me into the world of sustainable engineering. My community-involved approach resulted in a groundbreaking design, reducing indoor temperatures by 5 degrees Celsius during field tests. Beyond technical success, the initiative empowered communities with new skills and jobs, illustrating the transformative impact of sustainable engineering. My pursuit finds home within the ethos of Engineers without Borders (EWB) at Princeton. Amplifying my efforts through collaborative cross-functionality with EWB, I hope my dreams of sustainable engineering will transcend borders. Developing proper infrastructure and water facilities to underdeveloped areas in villages of all third peripheries, with EWB my vision expands trifold, limited by none other than my own imagination. Maria Garlock’s research on Innovative Structural Design for Earthquake, Fire, and Storm Surge runs parallel to mine at Punjab EPA, where I analyzed the impact of construction on the Murree- Tehsil region and studied the load-bearing capacity of 40+ structures. Under her guidance the horizon of disaster management’s amalgamation with engineering bypasses all dampers. For summers, the calling of home falls short in comparison to the excitement that researching at the Moini Lab offers. Joining Princeton's legacy, I see myself as a gardener, planting seeds of sustainable innovation in the fertile grounds of collaborative research and community engagement, nurturing them to blossom into solutions that cool the hearths of homes and warm the hearts of communities.

short_essay_2.prompt: Your Voice Princeton values community and encourages students, faculty, staff and leadership to engage in respectful conversations that can expand their perspectives and challenge their ideas and beliefs. As a prospective member of this community, reflect on how your lived experiences will impact the conversations you will have in the classroom, the dining hall or other campus spaces. What lessons have you learned in life thus far? What will your classmates learn from you? In short, how has your lived experience shaped you? (500 words or fewer)
short_essay_2.response: With soft loamy soil under my feet, I work barefoot - embarking on designing and constructing houses in Adrana. My work - despite the grit of the dirt beneath me, harkens me over the moon - as if I am a part of something larger - a pilgrimage. Embracing my role as a 3D Designer for the Architectural Project for the Homeless, in collaboration with the University of Punjab, I am entrusted with the task of crafting sustainable abodes for the homeless. Employing advanced computer-aided design (CAD) techniques, I meticulously develop intricate 3D prototypes, contributing to the comprehensive mapping of these structures. Under the invaluable guidance of esteemed professors dedicated to development, this journey embodies a commitment to forging positive change and creating havens of hope for those in need. This endeavor transcends mere mechanics; it's a journey, resonating with deep emotion and a profound attachment to the cause. These villages bear the lingering scars of devastating floods, entire regions in Punjab decimated, living spaces erased, and cherished ways of life obliterated. These communities are not strangers; they echo the familiar landscape of my own, sharing borders, and tragedies of rendering children my age homeless, without shelter, and utterly helpless: a fate that was mine in the 2011 floods as raging waters flooded our village and left us desolate and ravaged. I am now less enamored by scale, less galvanized by the prospect of beauty- my purpose, rather, has been extended to wanting to create an impact by safeguarding: a vanguard against the threats that echo every year. Now, I wish to reconstruct the community, and be a more active member of it entirely - my priorities have changed, marred by tragedy I vow to be the difference that protects others against the catastrophe that was mine. I am wary of taking life’s treasures for granted. Housing is a luxury for so many in my land- a matter of lottery, regardless of the shape and size it comes in. My eyes have opened to the sheer scale of disparities within housing rights, especially in rural villages similar to mine. Parallel to rural orthodoxies, how slums are inherently developed with a lack of sustainability, and yet, paradoxically, are the permanent homes for so many. I hope then, to combat this by ensuring sustainable material - even if this demands unanticipated aggressive crowdfunding efforts - for this is the obligation of the community - to safeguard, to protect, to share.

short_essay_3.prompt: Princeton has a longstanding commitment to understanding our responsibility to society through service and civic engagement. How does your own story intersect with these ideals? (250 words or fewer)
short_essay_3.response: In Pakistan, cultures are intricately linked, yet often, this connection is distant outside provincial borders. My life began at the cross-stitch of Punjab and Sindh - a vibrant intersection of Saraiki and Punjabi. My father from the former and mother from the latter, the language of love was often lost in translation. Despite warmth, there was a chill in the spaces between words understood and sentiments shared, a tangible testament to the division that language and culture sowed. It is from this personal narrative that Mushtarak was born. Within its embrace, 60+ people from diverse provincial backgrounds found a common language. We dismantled barriers with the gentle, persistent flow of mutual respect and understanding. Our workshops were not mere meetings; they were the loom on which we wove a new fabric of society, where the threads of cultural diversity strengthened rather than divided. With Mushtarak I have stood at the confluence of cultures, not as a bystander but as a bridge. Where once the words of my parents stumbled, lost in translation, I now find them in the smiles of children who speak the universal language of acceptance. From warmth of shared laughter in a Saraiki poem to strength found in a Punjabi proverb, I've learned that service is not just about building bridges but also about crossing them. In Mushtarak, I have not only founded an organization but fostered a family. Language of the heart is universal, and when we dare to speak it, the world listens and transforms.

application_narrative.overall_analysis: This application stands as a paradigm of narrative coherence and multidimensional excellence. The student successfully weaves a profound personal story of childhood deprivation into a mission-driven engineering and civic identity, showing growth from curiosity to leadership, from play to purpose. His spike in STEM — evidenced through research with governmental and university partners, prestigious competition outcomes, and deep CAD/3D technical experience — is rare and elite. But what distinguishes him further is the humanization of this STEM profile: every project addresses a social wound — housing crises, disability inclusion, cultural fragmentation, flood displacement. His service-driven ventures (EcoDwell, Khilonay, Mushtarak) are not performative but rooted in authentic lived experience, and he demonstrates not just empathy but a capacity to engineer solutions for systemic problems. His personal statement is emotionally layered, his supplements show institutional fit with Princeton’s Engineers Without Borders, and his essays center community healing over personal accolades. This applicant exemplifies what *The Gatekeepers* calls the 'citizen-scholar': intellectually driven, emotionally aware, civically rooted. His narrative reflects not only a world-class maker mindset but a moral compass oriented toward justice. Princeton would not merely admit him; it would be proud to amplify his impact.

personal_statement.essay_prompt: Share an essay on any topic of your choice. It can be one you've already written, one that responds to a different prompt, or one of your own design.
personal_statement.personal_statement:
Allow me to use this space to introduce you to my Books for they are, in essence, the one symbol, 
the one creation that I have, almost always, identified with. I read books to escape the grim reality 
of life, and oftentimes find it adding meaning and purpose to my life, connecting me with my inner 
self. My books are like “intersectionality” to Kimberley Crenshaw or “gender performativity” to 
Judith Butler or “hegemonic masculinity” to Raewyn Connell. So, without delay, allow me to 
introduce you to my books… 
 
Heer Ranjha by Waris Shah,  
 
Mirza Sahiban by Pilu,  
 
Sassi Punnu by Hashim.  
 
Each of these books are heirlooms of Punjabi folklore, treasured by young readers for their moral 
teachings. It was only natural for me to read these stories because it was my native language in 
Jhang, but more importantly, this was the only language my mother comprehended. My beautiful 
Amma Jan, wronged by conservative cultural norms, was divorced from attaining an education.  
 
Overtime, this created a gap between us. It was, however, Punjabi children’s stories that 
strengthened our bond and brought my mother out of isolation. I became increasingly conscious 
of the deep-seated issue prevalent in Pakistan regarding the under-education of women for I could 
have been one of them, but my mother recognised my affinity for reading and took a stand to 
ensure I would not face the very barriers she did. 
 
Biff, Chip and Kipper by Hunt and Brychta 
 
Charlotte’s Web by E. B. White,  
 
The Cat in the Hat by Dr. Seuss 
 
These classic English children’ books soon accumulated next to my Punjabi ones. Novel and crisp, 
these books in a foreign language ignited a force within me, a passion and motivation to learn. 
After all, I had followed my dreams and moved to Lahore to pursue an education. Nevertheless, it 
came with its downsides like having to wage a war back at home to receive permission to study, or 
be surrounded by men in public transport.  
 
But Lahore was the land of the books - a city that resembled a library of endless possibilities to 
learn. Unfortunately, these possibilities isolated my mother, once again, who was not proficient in 
English or Urdu (national language), she found herself constantly reminded of her past. I helplessly 
buried myself in the pages of my books, searching for an escape from reality… 
 
The ESL Survival Guide by Judie Haynes,  
CA Asghar, Fatima CEEB:  Fall 2025
9
FY REA CAID: 38700070
PREVIEW
 
English Vocabulary in Use by McCarthy and O’Dell,  
 
English for Everyone by Thomas Booth. 
 
The months following our move to Lahore saw me swearing by these books. Dedicated to helping 
my mother even though my proficiency was far from perfect and often ushered mockery. I lagged 
behind in class but I did not want to lose this battle, after all, if my mother could learn it then so 
could I!  
 
Journal of Teaching English Language,  
 
The Language Learning Journal,  
 
The Linguistic Review. 
 
With time, beginner level reading books transformed into digests, journals, research papers. My 
dreams appeared to be crystallizing, but there was always a looming reminder of my privilege, for 
hundreds of girls in my village did not have access to the same opportunities my mother and I 
enjoy, despite the substandard accommodation we inhabited. We realized that we had found an 
escape and needed to pave the way for our own back at home. So, with the help of some friends 
we made along the way, my mother and I set up “Nasal” (generation) in our home to uplift women 
in Jhang, connecting them to local handicraft exhibitions so that they can attain financial 
independence and pursue their dreams - regardless of whether they know English or Urdu.  
 
Heer Ranjha by Waris Shah,  
 
Mirza Sahiban by Pilu,  
 
Sassi Punnu by Hashim. 
 
We both find ourselves returning to the very books we started off with, hand in hand, we promise 
to continue on our mission - of learning and empowering.

education_progression.explanation: After completing my O Levels, I decided to return to Jhang, my native village, to advocate for rural women. I wanted to experience their lives more closely and learn the valuable skills they possess, such as embroidery, tapestry, stitching, and fabric painting. Living with them allowed me to acquire these skills, which helped me establish Nasal (Generation), a project aimed at providing financial stability for these women. Through this experience, I gained insight into the patriarchal cycle they endure and identified the key stakeholders contributing to it. One such stakeholder is the local molvi (religious scholar), who openly preaches that men should restrict women's mobility. By engaging with the women in my community, I was able to inform them about their rights and empower them to challenge these limitations.
education_progression.school_change_reasoning: I chose to leave my previous school due to its limited A-Level curriculum. Although there were many subjects offered, niche options like A-Level French were not available. Additionally, the school's policy required students to choose subjects from only one group, which restricted my ability to explore a diverse range of interests. I wanted the flexibility to discover new areas in my ALevels to better inform my choices for my bachelor’s degree. The National School became the ideal option, as they were willing to arrange teachers for any subject, even if only one student showed interest. This approach would allow me to pursue my passions without constraints.

short_essay_1.prompt: Idea or experience that makes you excited about learning
short_essay_1.response: My mother is put on trial by my Chachu (uncle), every-time I don my jeans. These confrontational exchanges occur frequently, labeling me ‘awara.’ (vulgar). The phrase echoes through our house and weighs heavily on my chest . Every word of my relatives’ accusations reminds me that I am being judged for crossing the arbitrary boundaries they have set for me. Mama refuses to see me as guilty. This social hatred contrasts my mother’s acceptance and creates a cognitive dissonance in me ; one that pushes me to explore the epistemological confusion about my beliefs. Habitually, I turn to books for answers. Reading The Long Silence, which follows Jaya, an Indian housewife trapped in a patriarchal family, reassures me that I am not wrong. Simone de Beauvoir’s The Second Sex asserts that “one is not born, but rather becomes, a woman” teaching me that gender identity is shaped by societal expectations. Judith Butler’s theory fully eradicates my dissonance: gender exists only through acts that express it. I realize being 'a woman' is not an inherent identity but a role one continuously performs. This understanding empowers me to stop performing and start being myself. I simply become because I am; free to be, free to live. This freedom entails a curiosity akin to liberation, one that follows neither the binary dictums of man nor woman, of neither jeans nor hijab. With this curiosity, I explore, from Spivak and Hird to Said and Oakley, my expected performance will no longer be my trial.

short_essay_2.response: Dear Roommate, I believe the things that define me are often what others might call 'weird.' Interestingly, ‘weird’ comes from the Old English ‘wyrd,’ meaning ‘fate’ or ‘destiny.’ Shakespeare’s Macbeth linked it to the supernatural, and by the 19th century, it came to mean something odd or out of place, often with a negative connotation. To me, weirdness is essential for innovation. My feminism, my anger, my happiness, my liberation, all deem me ‘weird’ back home. What are some of your oddities? Nothing fazes me, so I hope we find confidants amongst each other. Take Judith Butler, she challenged fixed notions of gender, and many found it aberrant, but they proved to be ground breaking. What are your ground breaking ideas? Do your thoughts run toward quantum physics or perhaps kitchen sink philosophy? Regardless of whether your big idea is a social concept, or an unhinged culinary craving (mine is Cheetos with ice cream), I am curious to listen to whatever you have to say. You’ll learn more about my ‘weird’ habits over time. One is that I like to paste black-and-white photos of influential people—dead or alive—along my bedside, from Joan of Arc to Taylor Swift. I will ensure I leave some space to paste personalities I learn about from you. Less weird: I can stitch! My best skill is breathing life back into frayed clothes, so if any of yours need a little revival, let me know. Looking forward to living together!
